intro: Panax guilfoylei, commonly known as the Guilfoyle’s ginseng, is a rare and endangered plant native to the rainforests of Queensland, Australia. It belongs to the Araliaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, fleshy, yellowish roots that are highly sought after for their medicinal properties. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments and has compound, serrated leaves that are adapted to low-light conditions. Its flowering occurs in late winter, producing small, greenish-white flowers that are followed by red, fleshy fruits. Due to its rarity and unique chemical composition, it is of significant interest to botanists and pharmacologists.
